questions.text: 25 years old man met with an accident. He underwent x-ray. X-ray image is shown below. Which nerve is most likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
• Its plane x-ray AP view, showing fracture of medial epicondyle of humerus.
    • The medial epicondyle of the humerus is a prominent bony projection on the medial side of the elbow.
    • It is subcutaneous and is easily felt on the medial side of the elbow.
  • Three nerves are directly related to the humerus: therefore, liable to injury
    • The axillary nerve at the surgical neck.
    • The radial nerve at the radial groove. (Option C)
    • The ulnar nerve is located behind the medial epicondyle. (Option A)
  • Median nerve (Option B) is injured in the supracondylar fracture of humerus presents as claw hand
  • Mussculocutaneous nerve (option D)pierces the coracobrachialis, also supplying brachialis and biceps brachii and continues as lateral cutaneous nerve of forearm

Tag: Bone of upper limb

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-1, 9th Edition, Page Number - 16, 17, 192

questions.text: Which of the following is forming the medial boundary of anatomical snuff box?
questions.solution:
• Anatomical snuff box:
  • It is a triangular depression on posterolateral side of the wrist. It seen best when the thumb is extended.
  • Boundaries :
    • Medial:
      • Extensor pollicis longus (Option B)
    • Lateral:
      • Extensor pollicis brevis (Option A) and abductor pollicis longus
    • Floor:
      • Scaphoid, trapezium, base of 1st metacarpal
    • Contents:
      • Superficial branch of radial nerve
      • Cephalic vein
      • Radial artery
  • The flexor pollicis longus (Option C) is a muscle of front of forearm and its tendon passes deep to flexor retinaculum.
  • The flexor pollicis brevis (Option D) is a muscle of thenar group in the palm.

Tag: Back of forearm

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-1, 9th Edition, Page Number - 148, 149

questions.text: Nerve supply of muscle shown in the figure below is?
questions.solution:
• Muscle shown in the figure is teres major.
  • Origin: Lower one-third of the dorsal surface of lateral border and inferior angle of the scapula
  • Insertion: Medial lip of the bicipital groove of the humerus
  • Nerve supply: Lower subscapular nerve (Option D)
  • Action: Medial rotator, adductor and extensor of arm.
  • Dorsal scapular nerve (Option A): It supplies to latissimus dorsi muscle.
  • Axillary nerve (Option B): It supplies to teres minor and deltoid muscles.
  • Upper subscapular nerve (Option C): It supplies to subscapularis muscle.

Tag: Back and scapular region

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-1, 9th Edition, Page Number - 77, 78

questions.text: Dermatome supplying to area marked with an arrow is?
questions.solution:
• Marked area is ventral aspect of the middle three digits (index, middle and ring fingers) and the adjoining area of the palm.
  • The cutaneous innervation of the upper limb is derived:
    • Mainly from segments C5-C8 and T1 of the spinal cord.
    • Partly from the overlapping segments from above (C3, C4) as well from below (T2, T3).
    • The additional segments are found only at the proximal end of the limb.
  • The dermatomes of the upper limb (Shown in figure below) are distributed in an orderly numerical sequence.
  • Along the preaxial border, by segments C3-C6 with overlapping of the dermatomes.
  • The middle three digits (index, middle and ring fingers) and the adjoining area of the palm are supplied by segment C7 (Option C).
  • The postaxial border is supplied (from below upwards) by segments C8, T1, T2.

Tag: Cutaneous supply of upper limb

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-1, 9th Edition, Page Number - 90, 91

questions.text: What is the root value of the nerve involved in winging of scapula?
questions.solution:
• Winging of the scapula:
  • It is excessive prominence of the medial border of the scapula during pushing movement.
  • It occurs due to injury to the nerve to serratus anterior (nerve of bell)
  • Nerve is also known as long thoracic nerve.
  • It is a branch of root C5, C6, C7 (Option C).
  • Causes:
    • Sudden pressure on the shoulder from above.
    • Carrying heavy loads on the shoulder.
  • Deformity: Winging of scapula
  • Disability:
    • Loss of pushing and punching actions. During attempts at pushing, there occurs winging of the scapula.
    • Overhead abduction of shoulder girdle is partly affected due to intact trapezius muscle.

Tag: Brachial plexus

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-1, 9th Edition, Page Number - 65

questions.text: Which of the following muscle is not supplied by musculocutaneous nerve?
questions.solution:
• Musculocutaneous nerve:
  • The musculocutaneous nerve is the main nerve of the front of the arm and continues below the elbow as the lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm.
  • It is a branch of the lateral cord of the brachial plexus.
  • Root value: Ventral rami of C5, C6, C7 segments of spinal cord.
  • Branches of musculocutaneous nerve:
    • Muscular branches:
      • Coracobrachialis (Option D)
      • Biceps brachii, long and short heads (Option C)
      • Brachialis (Option A)
    • Cutaneous branches: Lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm,
      • It supplies the skin of the lateral side of the forearm from the elbow to the wrist including the ball of the thumb.
    • Articular branches:
      • The elbow joint through its branch to the brachialis.
      • The shoulder joint through a separate branch which enters the humerus along with its nutrient artery.
  • Brachioradialis (Option B) is supplied by trunk of radial nerve in the cubital fossa.

Tag: Arm

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-1, 9th Edition, Page Number - 99 to 102

questions.text: 60 years old male patient visited neuro OPD with complaint of tingling sensation and paraesthesia on lateral half area of the palm. Which of the following nerve is likely to be involved?
questions.solution:
• Cutaneous supply of the hand is showing in the following Figure.

  • Median nerve (Option A):
    • Lateral two third of palm
    • Lateral 3½ digits
    • Dorsal aspect of distal phalanges of Lateral 3½ digits
  • Ulnar nerve (Option B):
    • Medial one third of palm
    • Lateral 1½ digits
    • Medial half including proximal and middle phalanges of medial 2½ digits
  • Radial nerve (Option C):
    • Lateral half including proximal and middle phalanges of lateral 2½ digits
  • Musculocutaneous nerve (Option D): Does not supply in the hand.

Tag: Hand

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-1, 9th Edition, Page Number - 88, 89

questions.text: The pectoralis major muscles is involved in the following actions, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Pectoralis major muscle:

  • Origin:
    • Front of trunk
  • Insertion:
    • It is inserted by a bilaminar tendon on the lateral lip of the bicipital groove in form of inverted "U"
  • Nerve Supply:
    • Medial pectoral nerve (C8, T1)
    • Lateral pectoral nerve (C5, C6, C8)
  • Actions:
    • Adduction(Otion B)
    • Flexion(Option A)
    • Medial rotation of arm(Option D)
    • So Option C is wrong.

KEY TAKE AWAYS - it is important to know the difference in action of pectoralis major and latissimus dorsi.

  • Pectoralis major - flexion, adduction , medial rotation
  • Latissimus dorsi - extension, adduction, medial rotation

Tag: Pectoral region

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-1, 9th Edition, Page Number - 46, 47

questions.text: All of the followings are growing end of that bone, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• The Growing end of long bones:
  • Upper limb
    1. Upper end of humerus (not lower end of humerus)- Option - A
    2. lower ends of radius (Option D)
    3. lower ends of ulna (Option C).
  • lower limb
    1. lower end of femur (Option B)
    2. upper end of tibia
  • The nutrient foramen is directed away from the growing end of the bone.
    • Their directions are indicated by a memory aid: 'Towards the elbow I go, from the knee I flee'.
    • Directions of nutrient foramen in the long bones are shown in the figure below.

Tag: General anatomy of bones

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-1, 9th Edition, Page Number - 67, 68

questions.text: Which of the following structure of the synovial joint is involved in rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
• Rheumatoid arthritis is an inflammatory systemic disease involving the synovial membranes (Option C) of small joints of the hands. Due to chronic inflammatory process there is deformity of the fingers.
  • Osteoarthritis is a degenerative condition of the large weight- bearing joints. The articular cartilage (Option B) wears out, degenerates and there is formation of peripheral osteophytes.
  • The degenerative changes or spondylitis may occur in the cervical spine, leading to narrowed intervertebral foramen, causing pressure on the spinal nerve.
  • Stiffness of joints related to weather. The viscosity of synovial fluid (Option D) increases with fall in temperature. This accounts for stiffness of the joints in cold weather.
  • Mobility of joint in itself is an important factor in promoting lubrication. Thus the stiffness of joints experienced in the morning gradually passes off as the movements are resumed.
  • Fibrous capsule (Option A) and ligaments possess a rich nerve supply, which makes them acutely sensitive to pain.

Key Takeaways:

Tag: General anatomy of joint

Reference: Textbook of General Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Page Number - 90

questions.text: Which of the following structures are passing through the quadrangular space?
questions.solution:
Quadrangular Space:

  • Superior boundary: teres minor
  • Inferior boundary: teres major.
  • Medial boundary : long head of the triceps brachii.
  • Lateral boundary : Surgical neck of the humerus.
  • Contents:
    • Axillary nerve
    • Posterior circumflex humeral vessels (Option A)

Upper triangular space:

  • Superior boundary: teres minor.
  • Lateral boundary: long head of the triceps brachii.
  • Inferior boundary: teres major.
  • Contents:
    • Circumflex scapular vessles (Option B)
      • Branch and tributaries of subsacpular vessels (Option D)

Lower triangular space

  • Medial boundary: long head of the triceps brachii.
  • Lateral boundary: Shaft of humerus.
  • Superior boundary: teres major.
  • Contents:
    • Radial nerve
    • Profunda brachii vessels (Option C)

Tag: Scapular region

Reference: Textbook of anatomy by Vishram Singh, Volume-3, 4th Edition, Page Number - 70, 71

choices.text: It is due to compression of median nerve under flexor retinaculum
Loss of sensation on lateral three and half part of palm

questions.text: 35 years old sportman came to OPD with C/O weakness and sensory loss in the palm. He was diagnosed with carpal tunnel syndrome. Which of the following is false about the patient?
questions.solution:
Carpal tunnel syndrome:

  • The median nerve (Option A) is injured in the carpal tunnel due to its compression under flexor retinaculum and produces a clinical condition called carpal tunnel syndrome.
  • The median nerve gets compressed in the tunnel due to its narrowing following a number of pathological conditions such as
    • Tenosynovitis of flexor tendons (idiopathic)
    • Diabetes mellitus
    • Myxedema (deficiency of thyroxine)
    • Retention of fluid in pregnancy
    • Fracture dislocation of lunate bone
  • Characteristic clinical features of the carpal tunnel syndrome are as follows:
    • burning pain or 'pins and needles' (i.e., lateral 3½ digits) especially at night.
    • There is no sensory loss over the thenar eminence (lateral side of palm) because skin over thenar eminence is supplied by the palmar cutaneous branch of the median nerve, which passes superficial to flexor retinaculum. So (Option B) is false about the given patient.
    • Weakness of thenar muscles (Option D).
    • 'Ape-thumb deformity' (Option C) may occur, if left untreated, due to paralysis of the thenar muscles.
    • Positive Tinel's sign and Phalen's test

Tag: The palm

Reference: Textbook of anatomy by Vishram Singh, Volume-3, 4th Edition, Page Number - 177, 178

questions.text: De Quervain's tenosynovitis of he first compartment of the extensor retinaculum is affecting which of the following tendon?
questions.solution:
• De Quervain tenosynovitis manifests as a thickening and myxoid degeneration of the tendon sheaths, specifically affecting the tendons passing through the fibro-osseous tunnel of extensor compartment of hand.
  • Most commonly affected tendons are abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis.

Structures in various compartments under extensor retinaculum

KEY NOTE – Finkle stein \ eichoffs test used – ulnar deviation of wrist with closed fist elicits pain

Tag: Dorsum of hand

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-1, 9th Edition, Page Number – 149, 150

Textbook of anatomy by Vishram Singh, Volume-3, 4th Edition, Page Number – 145, 123, 124

choices.text: Medial two lumbricals are supplied by median nerve
All are inserted into the dorsal digital expansion
They flex the metacarpophalangeal joint and extend the interphalangeal joint

questions.text: Which of the following is flase about the lumbricals in the hand?
questions.solution:
Lumbrical muscles:

  • Actions:
    • Flexion at metacarpophalangeal joint and Extension at proximal and distal interphalangeal joints (Option D).

Tag: The palm

Reference: Textbook of anatomy by Vishram Singh, Volume-3, 4th Edition, Page Number – 148, 149

questions.text: 50 years old cyclist came to OPD with injury at the medial side of wrist joint. On examination he was diagnosed with the ulnar nerve injury at gyon's canal. Which of the following muscle will not get affected in the patient?
questions.solution:
Ulnar canal syndrome/Guyon's tunnel syndrome:

  • It is clinical condition, which occurs due to compression of the ulnar nerve in Guyon's canal at wrist.
  • Clinically it presents as:
    • Hypoesthesia in medial 1½ fingers
    • Weakness of intrinsic muscles of hand.

Ulnar nerve in hand:.

  • Superficial Branch: it supplies
    • Palmaris brevis muscle
    • The digital nerves supply the skin of the medial 1½ finger.
    • The skin on the dorsum of distal phalanges of the medial 1½ finger.
  • Deep Branch: it supplies
    • Flexor digiti minimi (Option A)
    • Opponence digiti minimi
    • Abductor digiti minimi
    • Deep head of flexor pollicis brevis
    • Adductor pollicis (Option D)
    • Four dorsal interosseous muscles
    • Four palmar interosseous muscles (Option B)
    • Medial two lumbricals(3rd and 4th lumbricals)

Median nerve in hand:

  • Lateral division: it supplies
    • Abductor pollicis brevis
    • Superficial head of flexor pollicis brevis
    • Opponens pollicis (Option C)
    • 1st lumbrical
    • Sensory innervation to thumb and lateral side to the index finger (also dorsal aspect of distal phalynx)
  • Medial division: it supplies
    • Sensory innervation to the medial side of the index finger, middle finger, and lateral side of the ring finger (also dorsal aspect of distal phalynx).
    • 2nd lumbrical

Tag: The palm

Reference: Textbook of anatomy by Vishram Singh, Volume-3, 4th Edition, Page Number – 151, 152, 153
